articles.headline: As Robots Grow Smarter, American Workers Struggle to Keep Up
articles.snippet: Concern about technology — the printing press, the steam engine or the computer — supplanting humans is not new. But this time may be different.
articles.abstract: Concern about technology — the printing press, the steam engine or the computer — supplanting humans is not new. But this time may be different.
articles.lead_paragraph: A machine that administers sedatives recently began treating patients at a Seattle hospital. At a Silicon Valley hotel, a bellhop robot delivers items to people’s rooms. Last spring, a software algorithm wrote a breaking news article about an earthquake that The Los Angeles Times published.

articles.headline: Interest Rate Raised to 17% in Russia
articles.snippet: Western sanctions and the collapse in the price of oil have weighed on the economy and hurt the ruble.
articles.abstract: Western sanctions and the collapse in the price of oil have weighed on the economy and hurt the ruble.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has a new enemy: the currency markets.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: Classic Hip-Hop Is Spreading on the Radio Dial
articles.snippet: The format is sweeping the radio market in some cities, yielding one of the medium’s most enduring signs of success: a format turf war.
articles.abstract: The format is sweeping the radio market in some cities, yielding one of the medium’s most enduring signs of success: a format turf war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oldies radio used to mean Johnny Mathis and the Four Seasons. Now it’s Tupac Shakur and LL Cool J.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Premier Narrows Divide, but Challenges Loom
articles.snippet: The early performance of Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has encouraged Iraqi and Western officials, but his efforts are being tested by militants who control one-third of Iraq.
articles.abstract: The early performance of Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has encouraged Iraqi and Western officials, but his efforts are being tested by militants who control one-third of Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When an Iraqi court sentenced a prominent Sunni politician to death recently, it seemed like an unmitigated disaster for the country’s new prime minister, Haider al-Abadi.

articles.headline: Steven Cohen Seeks Ex-F.B.I. Agents to Join His Investment Firm
articles.snippet: The investor, who managed to fend off a criminal insider trading investigation of himself, is looking for an ex-prosecutor and several agents from the F.B.I. to join his new $10 billion firm.
articles.abstract: The investor, who managed to fend off a criminal insider trading investigation of himself, is looking for an ex-prosecutor and several agents from the F.B.I. to join his new $10 billion firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen beat them, and now he wants them to join him.

articles.headline: Economic Recovery Spreads to the Middle Class
articles.snippet: Many economists are convinced that falling unemployment and increased hiring are finally about to start paying off in terms of wage gains for a broader swath of workers.
articles.abstract: Many economists are convinced that falling unemployment and increased hiring are finally about to start paying off in terms of wage gains for a broader swath of workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, even as the economy recovered and the stock market soared, most American workers saw little evidence of better times in their paychecks.

articles.headline: Can’t Have Your Cake, Gays Are Told, and a Rights Battle Rises
articles.snippet: Local governments are taking a hard line against a small number of bakers, florists, photographers and others who are declining to provide services for same-sex weddings.
articles.abstract: Local governments are taking a hard line against a small number of bakers, florists, photographers and others who are declining to provide services for same-sex weddings.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKEWOOD, Colo. — Jack Phillips is a baker whose evangelical Protestant faith informs his business. There are no Halloween treats in his bakery — he does not see devils and witches as a laughing matter. He will not make erotic-themed pastries — they offend his sense of morality. And he declines cake orders for same-sex weddings because he believes Christianity teaches that homosexuality is wrong.

articles.headline: C.I.A., on Path to Torture, Chose Haste Over Analysis
articles.snippet: James Mitchell, a former Air Force trainer, and a partner designed, led and directed the interrogations and became the prime advocates for what is now widely considered to have been torture.
articles.abstract: James Mitchell, a former Air Force trainer, and a partner designed, led and directed the interrogations and became the prime advocates for what is now widely considered to have been torture.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost immediately after transferring the first important prisoner they had captured since the 9/11 attacks to a secret prison in Thailand, officials of the Central Intelligence Agency met at the agency’s headquarters to debate two questions they had been discussing for months. Who would interrogate Abu Zubaydah, and how?
articles.byline: By James Risen and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: From AMC and MoviePass, a Film a Day for a Monthly Fee
articles.snippet: A theater chain tries to reverse a decline in attendance, particularly with young moviegoers.
articles.abstract: A theater chain tries to reverse a decline in attendance, particularly with young moviegoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Netflix brought subscription-based movie and television streaming to the millennial masses. Spotify and Rhapsody did the same thing with music — pay once, listen to as much or as little as you want.

articles.headline: Taliban Besiege Pakistan School, Leaving 145 Dead
articles.snippet: The gunmen stormed a school in Peshawar, killing more than 100 students, along with teachers, during an eight-hour rampage in retaliation against the military, officials said.
articles.abstract: The gunmen stormed a school in Peshawar, killing more than 100 students, along with teachers, during an eight-hour rampage in retaliation against the military, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — First the Pakistani Taliban bombed or burned over 1,000 schools. Then they shot Malala Yousafzai, the teenage advocate for girls’ rights.
